column2: Kīsmāyū; Italian: Chisimaio) is a port city in the southern Lower Juba (Jubbada Hoose) province of Somalia. It is the commercial capital of the autonomous Jubaland region.

column1: The city is situated 528 kilometres (328 miles) southwest of Mogadishu
column2: near the mouth of the Jubba River
column3: where the waters empty into the Indian Ocean. According to the United Nations Development Programme
column4: the city of Kismayo had a population of around 89
column6: Kismayo and its surrounding area was part of the Ajuran Empire that governed much of southern Somalia and eastern Ethiopia
column7: with its domain extending from Hobyo in the north
column9: to Kismayo in the south.In the early modern period
column10: Kismayo was ruled by the Geledi Sultanate and by the later 1800s
column11: the Boqow dynasty. The kingdom was eventually incorporated into Italian Somaliland in 1910 after the death of the last sultan
column13: the city was made the center of the official Kismayo District.

column1: Kismayo was the site of numerous battles during the civil war
column2: from the early 1990s. In late 2006
column3: Islamist militants gained control of most of the city. To reclaim possession of the territory
column4: a new autonomous regional administration dubbed Azania was announced in 2010 and formalized in 2011. In September 2012
column5: the Somali National Army and AMISOM troops re-captured the city from the Al-Shabaab insurgents. The Juba Interim Administration was subsequently officially established and recognized in 2013.

column1: During antiquity. Kismayo was part of the Somali city-states that in engaged in a lucrative trade network connecting Somali merchants with Phoenicia
column2: Ptolemic Egypt
column3: Greece
column6: Nabataea and the Roman Empire. Somali sailors used the ancient Somali maritime vessel known as the beden to transport their cargo.

column1: === Middle Ages and the early modern period ===
The Kismayo area was originally a small fishing settlement.During the Middle Ages
column2: the region came under the rule of the influential Ajuran Sultanate
column3: which utilized the Jubba River for its plantations.

column1: After the collapse of this polity
column2: the House of Gobroon was established and the Sultanate of the Geledi held sway over the area. The dynasty reached its apex under the successive reigns of Sultan Yusuf Mahamud Ibrahim
column3: who successfully consolidated Gobroon power during the Bardera wars
column5: who forced regional powers such as the Omani Empire to submit tribute.

column2: Kismayo and other parts of Jubaland were claimed by the Sultanate of Muscat (now in Oman)
column3: when the new Sultanate of Zanzibar was split from Muscat and Oman and given control of its East African territories.

column2: Zanzibar became a British protectorate
column3: and on 1 July 1895
column4: the Sultanate ceded all of its coastal possessions in continental East Africa to Britain. Together with the Zanzibar Sultanate's other former possessions in the area
column5: Jubaland became part of the British East Africa colony.

column1: The Italians subsequently referred to the city as Chisimaio. Kismayo and the northern half of the Jubaland region were then incorporated into neighboring Italian Somaliland on 30 June 1926. The colony had a total area of 87
column3: 000 sq mi)
column5: 000 inhabitants. Britain retained control of the southern half of the partitioned Jubaland territory
column6: which was later called the Northern Frontier District (NFD).

column1: Following the breakdown of central authority that accompanied the civil war in 1991
column2: various local militias fought for control of the city
column3: including supporters of Mohammed Said Hersi ("General Morgan")
column4: and Col. Barre Adan Shire Hiiraale Somali National Front (SNF)
column5: later on known as the Juba Valley Alliance (JVA). As well of Col. Omar Jess' Somali Patriotic Movement (SPM). In March 1993
column6: a United States Marine amphibious group arrived in the city in an attempt to keep the peace as part of the United Nations intervention in Somalia. By December 1993
column8: despite the presence of peacekeepers. The last UN troops left the city in December 1994.

column1: General Morgan briefly declared Jubaland independent on September 3
column2: 1998. Political opponents of his subsequently united as the Allied Somali Forces (ASF)
column3: seizing control of Kismayo by June of the following year. Led by Colonel Barre Adan Shire Hiiraale
column4: the ASF administration renamed itself the Juba Valley Alliance in 2001. On June 18 of that year
column5: an 11-member interclan council decided to ally the JVA with the newly forming Transitional Federal Government.In 2006 the Islamic Courts Union (ICU)
column7: fought with Jubaland's inhabitants of the state the Darod Marehan (JVA). And invaded other parts of southern Somalia and promptly imposed Shari'a law. The Transitional Federal Government sought to re‑establish its authority
column9: with the assistance of Ethiopian troops
column10: African Union peacekeepers and air support by the United States
column11: managed to drive out the rival ICU and solidify its rule.On January 8
column13: as the Battle of Ras Kamboni raged just south of Kismayo
column14: the TFG relocated from its interim location in Baidoa to the nation's capital
column15: Mogadishu. This marked the first time since the fall of the Siad Barre regime in 1991 that the federal government controlled most of the country.Following this defeat
column16: the Islamic Courts Union splintered into several different factions. Some of the more radical elements
column18: regrouped to continue their insurgency against the TFG and oppose the Ethiopian military's presence in Somalia. Throughout 2007 and 2008
column20: seizing control of key towns and ports in both central and southern Somalia. By January 2009
column21: Al‑Shabaab and other militias had managed to force the Ethiopian troops to retreat
column22: leaving behind an under-equipped African Union peacekeeping force to assist the Transitional Federal Government's troops.In September 2012
column23: the Somali Army and AMISOM troops re-captured the city from the Al-Shabaab insurgents during the Battle of Kismayo (2012).On 12 July 2019
column24: a car bomb and a gun attack at the Asasey hotel killed at least 26
column25: including two prominent journalists and nine foreigners. Islamist group al-Shabab claimed responsibility.

column1: Kismayo is located in the fertile Juba Valley in southeastern Somalia
column2: on the Somali Sea coast. Nearby settlements include to the northeast Xamareyso (5.0 nm)
column3: to the north Dalxiiska (1.3 nm)
column4: to the northwest Qeyla Dheere (6.4 nm)
column6: to the southwest Iach Bulle (10.0 nm)
column7: and to the south Qandal (6.5 nm). The largest cities in the country most proximate to Kismayo are Jamaame (52 km)

column1: Kismayo has a hot semi-arid climate (Köppen climate classification BSh). Weather is hot year-round
column2: with seasonal monsoon winds and irregular rainfall with recurring droughts. The gu rains
column3: also known as the Southwest Monsoons
column4: begin in April and last until July producing significant fresh water and allowing lush vegetation to grow. The gu season is followed by the xagaa (hagaa) dry season.

column1: A new municipal district administration was established on 6 September 2008. Its members reportedly represented the ICU and Al‑Shabaab (three members each) in addition to a local clan (one member) which had played a part in the military assault. Representatives of the Islamic Courts Union questioned the legitimacy of the authority. On 1 October 2009
column2: Al Shabaab took full control of the city
column3: after Col. Barre Adan Shire Hiiraale self proclaim President of the (JVA) Jubaland state. And Sheikh Ahmed Madobe
column4: a senior commander of Ras Kamboni Brigade (then a part of Hizbul Islam)
column5: challenged Al‑Shabaab's control.With the subsequent ouster of the Al-Shabaab rebels in September 2012
column6: the Somali government began preparing mediations between the city's various stakeholders in order to establish an inclusive local administration. On 28 August 2013
column7: the autonomous Jubaland administration signed a national reconciliation agreement in Addis Ababa with the federal government. Endorsed by the federal State Minister for the Presidency Farah Abdulkadir on behalf of President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud
column8: the pact was brokered by the Foreign Ministry of Ethiopia and came after protracted bilateral talks.

column1: Under the terms of the agreement
column2: Jubaland is administered for a two-year period by a Juba Interim Administration and led by the region's incumbent president
column3: Ahmed Mohamed Islam. The regional president serves as the chairperson of a new Executive Council
column4: to which he appoints three deputies. Additionally
column5: the agreement includes the integration of Jubaland's military forces under the central command of the Somali National Army (SNA)
column6: and stipulates that the Juba Interim Administration will command the regional police.

column3: along the Kismayo–Mogadishu main road.

column1: Kismayo is the market center and commercial hub autonomous jubbaland region. Bank with a presence in Kismayo include salama bank and other many money remittance business.

column1: Kismayo's air transportation needs are served by Kismayo Airport
column2: which is situated about 10 km from the city. It was formerly a Somali Air Force training base. Following the outbreak of the civil war
column3: the airport was closed down for a period of time and its infrastructure was significantly damaged. However
column4: the facility was reopened in October 2008 by the Islamic Courts Union after undergoing some renovations. That same year
column5: the airport was also renamed after Imam Ahmed Gurey
column6: a 16th‑century Somali military leader.The Kismayo Airport was officially brought under the Juba Interim Administration in August 2013. Per agreement
column7: management of the facility was scheduled to be transferred to the Federal Government after a period of six months. Revenues and resources generated from the airport will also be earmarked for Jubaland's service delivery and security sectors as well as local institutional development.

column1: Three main thoroughfares connect Kismayo to other major areas in the country. The 600 km Highway 3 runs the length of the Juba Valley. Starting in Beled Hawo
column2: it goes through Garbaharey
column3: Bardera and Buale before finally reaching Kismayo.

column1: A paved 528 km freeway links the capital Mogadishu with Kismayo. A third highway extends northwest from Kismayo to Afmadow
column2: then turns toward Dhobley in the eastern part of the Gedo region.
the Interim Juba Administration launched a transport beautification and cleaning campaign in Kismayo. Part of a broader urbanization drive
column3: the initiative includes the clearing of clogged streets and lanes
column5: and further development of the municipal road network.

column1: Kismayo's large docks are situated on a peninsula on the Somali Sea coast. Formerly one of the Bajuni Islands
column2: the peninsula was subsequently connected by a narrow causeway when the modern Port of Kismayo was built in 1964 with U.S. assistance. The port served as a base for the Somali Navy as well as the Soviet Navy after the military coup in Somalia in 1969. Somalia and the United States jointly refurbished the port in 1984 after significant wear to the 2

column4: marginal wharf at the harbor required major renovations to maintain operations.The Port of Kismayo was officially brought under the Juba Interim Administration in August 2013. According to the agreement
